learning_outcomes.description: Read, interpret, and discuss world literature at university level.
Interpret and discuss the ways in which literature can participate in broader cultural and social debates.
Present your analysis and research in written form with appropriate professional skills in relation to presentation, expression, and referencing.

assessments.due_date:
Week 1 - Week 13

Each week in tutorials students will complete a 10 minute writing task in response to a question based on that week's readings.
assessments.task_description:
Each week in tutorials we will set a 10 minute writing task, in which you write a response to a question based on that week's readings. Responses will be submitted through an online portal in Blackboard and must be submitted within 24 hours of your tutorial: we recommend you do it immediately. These are marked on a pass/fail basis and can earn you 1% towards your final grade. Participating in a research plan workshop in Week 9 tutorials can earn up to 6% of your final grade.

Rationale: Consistent preparation and participation lead to better learning outcomes and more productive and enjoyable learning experiences. Through participation, humanities students gain a highly valued and distinctive skill set in critical thinking, discipline mastery, evidence-based learning, and collaboration. These skills are required by many workplaces. The ability to write on a set topic and within a short time frame is a valuable academic and vocational skill, and it helps you to track your learning and prepare for written assessment tasks. Finally, this assessment item provides basic weekly feedback throughout the semester.

Use of Generative AI: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Responses will be submitted through an online portal in Blackboard and must be submitted during your tutorial.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment item requires a close engagement with at least one (1) of the short readings discussed in week 2 in relation to Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie's novel Americanah. A detailed topic sheet will be made available in Blackboard during semester. The essay must be correctly formatted with a bibliography in MLA 9th edition, guidelines for which are accessible through the UQ Library. Care should be given to expression, punctuation, and grammar.

Use of Generative AI: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Essay 2 requires students to engage with scholarly criticism and selected literary texts from weeks 6-9 in the course. The tasks will involve secondary research as well as close readings of two (2) of the following set novels: Fred D'Aguiar Feeding the Ghosts; Monica Ali Brick Lane; and / or Salman Rushdie The Moor's Last Sigh. Essay topics will be made available in Blackboard during semester. The essay must be correctly formatted with a bibliography in MLA 9th edition, guidelines for which are accessible through the UQ Library. Care should be given to expression, punctuation, and grammar.

Use of Generative AI: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. While students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment task will require you to write a reflective essay on M NourBese Philip's Zong! and Patricia Grace's Baby No-Eyes that demonstrates your understanding of decolonisation. This task will also give you the opportunity to consider key issues we have studied in the course. The essay must be correctly formatted with a bibliography in MLA 9th edition, guidelines for which are accessible through the UQ Library. Care should be given to expression, punctuation, and grammar.

Use of Generative AI: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Drop-in tutorial_Reading Decolonising Texts & Preparing for Exams

Each tutorial group can decide how to use this class. You may like a "shut up & read" read session to cover the exciting and challenging texts in the final part of ENGL2080. Or you might chose to get some practice in reading poetry out loud (Zong! is a profoundly oral text, & we will be watching some performances of it in lectures). Semester 2, 2025 will also see the roll out of regular examinations in ENGL courses (and beyond) in response to UQ's new academic integrity policies, so you may like to learn more about how to prepare for your ENGL2080 exam and share tips and strategies about maximising your writing quality and time under exam conditions. Because of the student-led nature of the Week 11 tutorial, there will not be a Management of Learning task this week.


Learning outcomes: L03
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 11: Drop-in tutorial_Reading Decolonising Texts & Preparing for Exams

Or you might chose to get some practice in reading poetry out loud ( Zong! is a profoundly oral text, & we will be watching some performances of it in lectures). Semester 2, 2025 will also see the roll out of regular examinations in ENGL courses (and beyond) in response to UQ's new academic integrity policies, so you may like to learn more about how to prepare for your ENGL2080 exam and share tips and strategies about maximising your writing quality and time under exam conditions.
